wlv.mt.aren
Class FeatureExtractor

java.lang.Object
  wlv.mt.AbstractFeatureExtractor
      wlv.mt.aren.FeatureExtractor

public class FeatureExtractor
extends AbstractFeatureExtractor

FeatureExtractor extracts Glassbox and/or Blackbox features from a pair of source-target input files and a set of additional resources specified as input parameters Usage: FeatureExtractor -input -lang -feat [list of features] -mode [gb|bb|all] -gb [list of GB resources] -rebuild -log
The valid arguments are:
-help : print project help information
-input : the input source and target files
-lang : source and target language
-feat : the list of features. By default, all features corresponding to the selected mode will be included
-gb [list of files] input files required for computing the glassbox features
The arguments sent to the gb option depend on the MT system -mode
-rebuild : run all preprocessing tools
-log : enable logging
-config : use the configuration file

Author:
Catalina Hallett

parseArguments

public void parseArguments(java.lang.String[] args)
Parses the command line arguments and sets the respective fields accordingly. This function sets the input source and target files, the source and target language, the running mode (gb or bb), the additional files required by the GB feature extractor, the rebuild and log options

Specified by:

Computes the perplexity and log probability for the POS tagged target file
Required by BB features 68-69
This function could be merged with @seerunNGramPPL() but I separated them to make the code more readable

Parameters:
posFile - file tagged with parts-of-speech

preprocessing

protected void preprocessing()
Performs some basic processing of the input source and target files For English, this consists of converting the input to lower case and tokenizing For Arabic, this consists of transliteration and tokenization. Please note that the current tools used for tokenizing Arabic also perform POS tagging and morphological analysis Although we could separate the tokenization process from the more in-depth text analysis performed by these tools, for efficiency reasons this is not desirable The input files are also copied to the /input folder. This is necessary because the MADA analyser produces its output in the same folder as the input file, which may cause problems if the right access rights are not available for that particular folder

Overrides:
preprocessing in class AbstractFeatureExtractor

processNGrams

private LanguageModel processNGrams()

runAll

public void runAll()
Specified by:
runAll in class AbstractFeatureExtractor

constructFolders

public void constructFolders()
constructs the folders required by the application. These are, typically:
  • /input and subfolders
    • /input/sourceLang, /input/targetLang (for storing the results of processing the input files with various tools, such as pos tagger, transliterator, morphological analyser),
    • /input/systems/systemName (for storing system specific resources - for example, the compiled and processed word lattices in the case of the IBM system
  • /output (for storing the resulting feature files),

Overrides:
constructFolders in class AbstractFeatureExtractor

initialiseGBResources

public java.lang.String initialiseGBResources()
identifies which MT system is used and constructs the xml file that describes the features specific to a particular MT system

Returns:
the path to the XML file
